sen.j: 河俣神社（かわまたじんじゃ）は、奈良県橿原市にある神社である。
sen.e: Kawamata-jinja Shrine is located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Kawamata-jinja Shrine is located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Kawamata-jinja Shrine is located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は村社。
sen.e: The shrine rank is shikinaisha (shrine listed on Engishikijinmyocho which was complied in 927) and sonsha (shrine taken care of by a village) in the old shrine ranking system.
The shrine rank is shikinaisha (shrine listed on Engishikijinmyocho which was complied in 927) and sonsha (shrine taken care of by a village) in the old shrine ranking system.
The shrine rank is shikinaisha (shrine listed on Engishikijinmyocho which was complied in 927) and sonsha (shrine taken care of by a village) in the old shrine ranking system.
Kotoshironushi (a Japanese ancient god) is enshrined.
Kotoshironushi (an ancient Japanese god) is enshrined.
Kotoshironushi (an ancient Japanese god) is enshrined.
History
History
History

sen.j: 『出雲国造神賀詞』に皇室を守護する神として「事代主命の御魂を宇奈提の神奈備に坐せ」とある。
sen.e: "Izumono kokuso kamuyogoto" (an invocation of the god) described that 'the soul of Kotoshironushi no mikoto was enshrined in kannabi (sacred place where souls of gods get together) of unase' as a god to protect the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Izumono kokuso kamuyogoto" (an invocation of the god) described that 'the soul of Kotoshironushi no mikoto was enshrined in kannabi (sacred place where souls of gods get together) of unase' as a god to protect the Imperial family.

"Izumono kokuso kamuyogoto" (an invocation of the god) described that 'the soul of Kotoshironushi no mikoto was enshrined in kannabi (sacred place where souls of gods get together) of unase' as a god to protect the Imperial family.

sen.j: この「宇奈提（うなせ）」は「雲梯（うなて）」のことであるとして、延喜式神名帳に記載される式内大社「大和国高市郡 高市御坐鴨事代主神社」に比定されている。
sen.e: This 'unase' means 'unate', which suggests that it is considered as shikinaitaisha listed on Engishikijinmyocho, 'Yamato no kuni takechi-gun, Takechinomiimasukamono kotoshiro-jinjja Shrine'.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This 'unase' means 'unate', which suggests that it is considered a shikinaitaisha listed on Engishikijinmyocho, 'Yamato no kuni takechi-gun, Takechinomiimasukamono kotoshiro-jinjja Shrine'.
This 'unase' means 'unate,' which suggests that it is considered a shikinaitaisha listed on Engishikijinmyocho, 'Yamato no kuni takechi-gun, Takechinomiimasukamono kotoshiro-jinjja Shrine.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド、カンマの位置

sen.j: （延喜式神名帳には「川俣神社三座」という社名が見えるが、これは近くの木葉神社に比定されている）。
sen.e: (The shrine name of 'kawamata-jinja Shrine sanza' appeared in Engishikijinmyocho, but this is considered as Konoha-jinja Shrine near Kawamata-jinja Shrine.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (The shrine name of 'kawamata-jinja Shrine sanza' appeared in Engishikijinmyocho, but this is considered as Konoha-jinja Shrine near Kawamata-jinja Shrine.)
(The shrine name of 'kawamata-jinja Shrine sanza' appeared in Engishikijinmyocho, but this is considered as Konoha-jinja Shrine near Kawamata-jinja Shrine.)

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によれば、壬申の乱の際、高市郡大領高市縣主許梅に「高市社に居る事代主神」が神懸りし、大海人皇子（後の天武天皇）を守護すると神託した。
sen.e: Nihonshoki' (Chronicles of Japan) indicated that in the time of Jinshin War, Dairyo (the highest-ranking local officer) in Takechi-gun, Takechi no agatanushi kome was possessed by the soul of Kotoshironushi no kami supernaturally and delivered a divine message that the god of the shrine would protect Oama no miko (later the Emperor Tenmu).

Nihonshoki' (Chronicles of Japan) indicated that in the time of the Jinshin War, Dairyo (the highest-ranking local officer) in Takechi-gun, Takechi no agatanushi kome was possessed by the soul of Kotoshironushi no kami supernaturally and delivered a divine message that the god of the shrine would protect Oama no miko (later the Emperor Tenmu).

Nihonshoki' (Chronicles of Japan) indicated that in the time of the Jinshin War, Dairyo (the highest-ranking local officer) in Takechi-gun, Takechi no agatanushi kome was possessed by the soul of Kotoshironushi no kami supernaturally and delivered a divine message that the god of the shrine would protect Oama no miko (later the Emperor Tenmu).

sen.j: 大海人皇子の即位後、この霊験により、高市御坐鴨事代主神に、史上初となる神位が授けられている。
sen.e: After Oamano miko was enthroned, Takechinomiimasukamono kotoshironushi no kami received shini (the rank of deity) for the first time in the history due to that miraculous efficacy.
After Oamano miko was enthroned, Takechinomiimasukamono kotoshironushi no kami received shini (the rank of deity) for the first time in the history due to that miraculous efficacy.
After Oamano miko was enthroned, Takechinomiimasukamono kotoshironushi no kami received shini (the rank of deity) for the first time in the history due to that miraculous efficacy.

sen.j: 万葉集にも当社のことを詠んだ歌がある。
sen.e: There is tanka in Manyoshu (the oldest anthology of tanka) about this shrine.
There is tanka in Manyoshu (the oldest anthology of tanka) about this shrine.
There is tanka in Manyoshu (the oldest anthology of tanka) about this shrine.

sen.j: 住吉大社（大阪市住吉区）には畝傍山口神社境内における埴取の神事がある。
sen.e: There is an event for clay soil in the precincts of Unebi yamaguchi-jinja Shrine in Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka City).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is an event for clay soil in the precincts of Unebi yamaguchi-jinja Shrine in Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka City).
There is an event for clay soil in the precincts of Unebi yamaguchi-jinja Shrine in Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka City).

sen.j: その祭祀を行う者は当社で装束を整えることが恒例となっており、そのことから「装束の宮」と俗称される。
sen.e: A priest who handles the event completes his costume in Kawamta-jinja Shrine as is customary, therefore, it is also commonly called 'shozoku no miya' (a shine of costume).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A priest who handles the event completes his costume in Kawamta-jinja Shrine as is customary, therefore, it is also commonly called 'shozoku no miya' (a shrine of costume).
